awd_titl_txt: UNS:Collaborative Research: Coded-illumination Fourier Ptychography for High-content Multimodal Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Collaborative)
PI: Zheng, Guoan
Proposal:1510077

PI: DiMarzio, Charles
Proposal: 1510280

This project will develop a new prototype microscope of ultra-high sensitivity with super-high resolution, yet with the ability to provide 3D imaging at a large field-of-view and rapid imaging.


The proposal aims to develop a new type of microscopy technique, (coded-illumination Fourier ptychography), that incorporates the innovations of novel Fourier data recovery, structured illumination for tissue sectioning, multi-layer modeling, and spectrum multiplexing. Iteration across data acquisitions is used to optimize to a final image solution. Increased image dimensionality, either spectral or spatial, is a highly desired commodity. If these techniques can be made routine, then many areas of microscopy could benefit. The proposal reflects substantial outreach to women and significant educational efforts towards graduates and undergraduates.

.

por.por_cntn:
Despite the rapid progress in biomedical optics in the past decade, there is a pressing need for higher information content in images. One application area is tissue sample imaging with cellular-level resolution. This problem remains a challenge due to the multiple scattering process in biological tissues. Scanning confocal reflectance microscope is a popular technique for this application as it provides the ability to microscopically evaluate cellular and sub-cellular features in tissues in vivo. It allows real-time assessment of the histopathological properties which may improve diagnostic yield by guiding biopsy. The label-free nature of confocal reflectance microscopy in particular has propelled it into the clinical realm. However, there are also some limitations associated with the conventional confocal microscope platform. First, it requires point-scanning of the optical system with mechanical components and complicated optical relays. To be medically useful, multiple images of tissue samples must be stitched together in a process that is time-consuming, and susceptible to artifacts induced by uneven brightness and patient motion. Furthermore, high-resolution often requires the use of high-magnification lenses, leading to short working distances and limited field-of-view. The ability to obtain images having a high pixel count without these difficulties would make the characterization of tissue samples more effective.

In this NSF project, an imaging framework based on coded illumination has been developed for high-content imaging. The 3D sample is modeled as multiple layers along the optical axis. The multi-slice Fourier ptychographic reconstruction process is used to update the transmission profiles of these different layers. Similarly, the same recovery strategy can be used to extract the spectroscopic information from the captured data. In this case, images at different wavelengths can be recovered from the incoherent mixture of the raw measurements. The findings of this project enable new developments for 3D microscopy and spectroscopy. High information content with a large field of view and high resolution can be obtained by the Fourier ptychography technique without involving mechanical scanning. The broader impacts of this project include curriculum development, and research training of undergraduate students and high-school students, including those from underrepresented groups.
